content: so you've made yourself something really cool out of styrofoam but you need to
know what's the best way to protect it hey guys pillow pow today I want
to cover something that I think is really important if you're like me you
build a lot of stuff out of styrofoam or foam board it's a wonderful material
that lends itself to a lot of different projects you can sculpt it you can sand
it you can carve it you can paint it you can do anything anything that people
sculpt or cast I can make out of styrofoam or very very cheap the one
downside to styrofoam is that despite its versatility it's a very soft
material so if you spend a lot of time carving something a lot of intricate
pieces you want to protect it and you want to make it hold up for a long time
so people always ask me what I do to seal or protect my pieces it depends on
a few things if I'm making something small like a table or say a dungeon tile
that's made out of only one piece of styrofoam no bits glued together I make
the piece I paint it and then I only seal it in the finishing stages if I'm
making something like one of the buildings that has a lot of small pieces
that are glued in place before painting I will give everything a coat in either
watered-down PVA or more recently Mod Podge this makes the surface quite a bit
harder but the most important thing is that it gets in all the little crevices
or two pieces joint and ensures that the bond is going to hold up over time I
know a lot of people like to spray-paint their work black or spray paint it with
primer this is something that I do not do I put too much work into my builds to
risk the styrofoam melting you can give a piece a couple coats of Mod Podge or
PVA and then spray-paint it and in theory it should be fine but there's
always a chance that you missed a spot and I figure if you're going to take the
time brushing on the watered-down PVA or Mod Podge you could have just brushed on
the black paint and been done so I personally don't spray paint stuff
the styrofoam if you're gonna do it I recommend a couple coats of the glue or
Mod Podge and I also recommend mixing in a bit of paint to that so that you can
see if you missed anywhere the main reason that I can get away with
not spray bombing stuff or coating it in glue before the final stage is because I
have found a way to finish my pieces with an aerosol spray that makes them
hard and durable but that does not melt the styrofoam my best friend
Minna wax polyurethane spray it comes in different finishes satin semi-gloss and
a full gloss and every piece that I make out of styrofoam gets finished with two
to three coats of this stuff and if you're following along you will know
that a lot of pieces I don't coat in any sort of glue I carve the piece I paint
it with acrylic paint and then I spray it with this because by some miracle
Minnewaska polyurethane does not melt foam I don't know why I'm not a chemist
I it should I would think but it doesn't I've sprayed this on raw foam a couple
inches away and it doesn't melt it so I can spend 80 hours carving a detailed
building paint it and then finish it with this at the end without fear of it
melting once a piece gets a few coats of that polyurethane it's nice and durable
it's going to lock in all your paint it's not going to chip over time it
doesn't make the piece rock-hard I mean it is still styrofoam I guess if you put
enough coat on it would get raw card this is where I actually like styrofoam
overcast pieces yeah it's not as hard but here's the thing
I dropped it it hit the floor if that was a piece of cast dental plaster or
whatever it would have shattered because it's styrofoam just bounces the clear
coat protects the finish there's no paint chips so that is my preferred
method but one word of warning not all polyurethane sprays are created
equal everything which is another brand makes
basically the exact same product take clear polyurethane spray this will melt
the out of your styrofoam again I don't know why this one will melt it and
this one won't when essentially they're the same product I don't know it doesn't
matter but what's important is that I'm telling you to spray your stuff with
polyurethane don't go to the store and buy this and then come to me crying when
it melts it a bunch of different brands make this stuff it's not just Bayer
Thane and minnow actors also rust-oleum and a handful others I can't speak for
the other brand I haven't tested them so my recommendation to you is to go out
and try to buy the minnow ox stuff if you can't find it buy something
different other than this one and test it out on some raw foam and I'd say even
if you buy this stuff before you hit your first project on it spray a piece
of raw styrofoam just to make sure that for some reason the stuff sold in your
area versus mine isn't somehow different if you can spray this stuff from a
couple inches away on raw styrofoam and it doesn't melt then you're cold so I
hope that little tip helps you guys out like I said it is one of my favourite
tools in my shop I cover just about everything with it if you liked this
video please smash the like button drown already a subscriber hit subscribe and
of course you can join me over on Facebook in the description below is a
link to the black magic craft Facebook page that's where I post pictures on a
very regular basis short videos both the stuff I'm working on it's also a great
way that you can comment or post pictures of your work or message me and
ask questions that you may have so until next time Cheers
